Introduction

Esophageal cancer is a malignant neoplasm arising from the epithelial lining of the esophagus.  Although less common than many other gastrointestinal malignancies, it often presents at advanced stages and carries a poor prognosis.  Globally, squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) remains the main histologic subtype, especially in Asia and Africa, whereas adenocarcinoma predominates in countries in the Western hemisphere.  These differences reflect varying risk factors:  In adenocarcinoma-predominant regions, obesity, gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and dietary habits play a role, whereas tobacco, alcohol, and hot beverages predominate in SCC-predominant regions.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



Esophageal cancer develops through a progression from normal epithelium to dysplasia and, ultimately, invasive malignancy.  The main subtypesâ€”SCC and adenocarcinomaâ€”arise via distinct pathways, tend to occur in different regions of the esophagus, and have unique risk factors (

Squamous cell carcinoma



SCC originates from the native stratified squamous epithelium, usually in the proximal or middle third of the esophagus.  Chronic irritation and inflammation underlie its pathogenesis.  Common insults include tobacco smoking, heavy alcohol use, ingestion of very hot beverages, ingestion of N-nitroso compounds (eg, cured meats), and underlying esophageal conditions (eg, achalasia).  Over time, repeated injury leads to squamous dysplasia and eventual malignant transformation.

Adenocarcinoma



Adenocarcinoma typically arises in the lower third of the esophagus, often from Barrett esophagus, a condition in which chronic GERD leads to replacement of the normal squamous lining by intestinal-type columnar epithelium (

) (
image 1
) (discussed in a separate article).  This metaplastic change increases the risk for dysplasia and eventual malignant transformation.  Risk factors such as obesity (predisposes to acid reflux), and consumption of nitrate-rich, processed foods further promote Barrett changes and adenocarcinoma development.  Aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs may have a slight protective effect.

Clinical presentation and diagnosis



Although SCC and adenocarcinoma arise from distinct pathogenic mechanisms and have different risk factor profiles, their clinical presentations overlap significantly.  Both subtypes often present late in the disease course with similar symptom patterns, making symptom-based differentiation unreliable.  Symptoms include:



  • Progressive dysphagia:  Progressive dysphagia typically starts with solids and eventually involves softer foods and liquids as the tumor narrows the lumen.
  • Weight loss:  Loss of weight is often substantial and involuntary, reflecting both mechanical obstruction and tumor-associated metabolic changes.
  • Retrosternal discomfort or pain:  Persistent burning, chest pain, or discomfort may mimic chronic GERD.
  • Lymph node metastasis:  SCC typically involves the mediastinal lymph nodes (eg, upper thoracic and paratracheal nodes), whereas adenocarcinoma more often spreads to the abdominal lymph nodes (eg, gastric and celiac nodes).


Patients age >50 and those with alarm featuresâ€”such as gastrointestinal bleeding (overt or occult), persistent vomiting, or rapidly worsening dysphagiaâ€”warrant immediate endoscopic evaluation.  In the absence of alarm symptoms, barium swallow or esophageal manometry may be considered in some patients (

image 2
).  Upper endoscopy with biopsy allows direct visualization of suspicious lesions and histologic examination to distinguish between subtypes:



  • SCC:  Pathologic results are characterized by nests or sheets of atypical squamous cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm, distinct cell borders, keratin pearls, and intercellular bridges (
    image 3
    ).
  • Adenocarcinoma:  Findings include irregularly shaped, malignant glandular structures composed of dysplastic, mucin-producing cells (
    image 4
    ).

Staging



Accurate staging is crucial for determining the appropriate treatment strategy.  The tumor-node-metastasis (TNM) system defines the depth of tumor invasion (T stage), the presence and extent of regional lymph node involvement (N stage), and the presence of distant metastases (M stage).  Staging modalities include:



  • Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS):  The combination of endoscopy and ultrasonography provides a detailed assessment of tumor depth (T stage) and nearby lymph nodes.  EUS-guided fine-needle aspiration can confirm nodal metastases.
  • CT scan and positron emission tomography (PET)/CT scan:  Contrast-enhanced CT scans and integrated PET/CT imaging identify metastatic disease not visible on endoscopy alone.  PET/CT imaging often detects distant metastases, preventing unnecessary surgery.
  • Bronchoscopy and laryngoscopy (for upper lesions):  In tumors at or above the carina, evaluation of the airways helps rule out invasion into the tracheobronchial tree.  For cervical SCCs, flexible laryngoscopy is performed to exclude synchronous head and neck cancers.
  • Laparoscopy (for distal/gastroesophageal junction [GEJ] lesions):  In some patients with distal esophageal or GEJ adenocarcinomas, diagnostic laparoscopy may detect peritoneal metastases missed by imaging.

Management



Treatment depends on histology, stage, and patient fitness.  Tailored approaches using biologically targeted therapies and immunotherapies are evolving, particularly for adenocarcinoma.  Differences in genomic alterations between SCC and adenocarcinomas may guide future targeted treatments.

Localized or early-stage disease



  • Endoscopic resection (for very early tumors):  Early, superficial cancers confined to the mucosa may be amenable to curative endoscopic resection.
  • Surgical resection:  Esophagectomy remains a primary curative option for more advanced, localized disease.

Locally advanced disease



  • Neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy:  Neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy is administered before surgery to shrink tumors and improve resectability.
  • Definitive chemoradiotherapy:  For patients who are not surgical candidates, combined therapy may provide local control and palliation.

Metastatic or advanced disease



  • Palliative chemotherapy and/or radiotherapy:  Extends survival modestly and improves quality of life.
  • Endoscopic stenting:  Relieves obstruction to improve swallowing and nutrition.
  • Supportive and nutritional care:  Essential to maintain quality of life.

Prognosis and screening



The prognosis in esophageal cancer correlates closely with the stage at diagnosis; early detection and intervention improve outcomes, whereas advanced disease is associated with poor survival.  No universal screening programs exist for the general population due to low incidence and cost-effectiveness concerns, but certain high-risk groups may benefit from surveillance.  Patients with long-standing GERD, Barrett esophagus, and additional risk factors (eg, obesity, smoking, age >50) may undergo periodic endoscopy to identify dysplasia or early-stage adenocarcinoma.  In regions with a high incidence of SCC, targeted surveillance strategies are sometimes considered, although protocols vary.

Summary



Esophageal cancer is most commonly either squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) or adenocarcinoma.  SCC is associated with smoking, alcohol, and thermal injury, whereas adenocarcinoma often arises from Barrett esophagus due to long-standing gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).  Patients typically present with progressive solid-food dysphagia, weight loss, and sometimes retrosternal discomfort.  Diagnosis requires endoscopy with biopsy, and staging uses endoscopic ultrasonography and imaging.  Treatment depends on stage and may involve endoscopic therapy, surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation.  The prognosis worsens with more advanced disease, and prevention focuses on addressing risk factors such as smoking, obesity, and GERD.
